deliberation: Checked whether the vocative בֶּן־אָדָם ('son of man' / 'mortal') is figurative (idiom, metonymy) and whether 'stand on your feet' functions metaphorically for readiness. In context it serves as a literal designation of Ezekiel’s humanity before God and a literal command to change posture (from prostrate to standing). No clear rhetorical or figurative device beyond normal narrative description.

Considered whether 'a spirit entered into me and set me on my feet' personifies 'spirit' or uses metaphor for empowerment. In Ezekiel's visionary narrative, רוּחַ consistently denotes an actual divine/spiritual agency, not a non-personal abstraction. The movement from prone to standing is part of the visionary action, not an overt metaphor. Thus I treat this as visionary-literal rather than a rhetorical figure.

Examined the labels 'nation of rebels' (גּוֹיִם הַמּוֹרְדִים), 'have rebelled against Me' (מָרְדוּ־בִי), and 'have defied/transgressed against Me' (פָּשְׁעוּ בִי). These extend political insurrection language to covenant violation, a standard prophetic conceptual metaphor. I treat the cluster of rebellion terms as a single figurative mapping (sin as political rebellion). Other elements of the verse are straightforward historical/theological description.

instances.explanation: Terms for political revolt ('rebels,' 'rebelled against Me,' 'transgressed against Me') are transferred from the sphere of human politics to describe Israel’s religious disobedience to God, picturing sin as treason against a divine king.

deliberation: Focused on the descriptions קְשֵׁי פָנִים ('hard/brazen of face') and חִזְקֵי־לֵב ('hard/strong of heart'). Both use bodily terms (face, heart) and physical hardness to represent moral-attitudinal traits (shamelessness, stubborn will). These are distinct but related metaphors and also involve synecdoche (face and heart for the whole person’s stance).

deliberation: The key phrase is בֵּית מְרִי ('rebellious house'). Here 'house' is a conventional metonym/synecdoche for a family, dynasty, or communal group, and the entire community is labeled by the abstract quality 'rebellion.' I treat this as one figurative expression (primarily metonymy with synecdochic nuance). Other elements are straightforward.

instances.explanation: The term 'house' stands metonymically and synecdochically for the whole community, and that community is defined by the abstract noun 'rebellion.' It pictures Israel as a lineage or household whose hallmark is insubordination.

deliberation: This verse is rich in imagery. I examined (1) סָרָבִים וְסַלּוֹנִים ('thistles and thorns') in relation to the prophet, (2) 'you sit among scorpions' as an image of his environment, and (3) the repeated label בֵּית מְרִי ('rebellious house'). The plant and scorpion imagery function as metaphors for the people’s hostility and the painful danger of their opposition. 'Rebellious house' is again a metonymy for the community.

deliberation: The notable phrase is כִּ֥י מְרִ֖י הֵֽמָּה ('for they are rebellious'). The noun מְרִי literally means 'rebellion' and is used in political contexts, but here it is predicated of the people’s religious stance toward God, extending political-revolt terminology into the theological sphere. I treat this as a concise instance of the same sin-as-rebellion metaphor seen earlier.

ground: defiance, refusal of obedience to rightful authority

posture: summarizing Israel’s identity in political terms of revolt
instances.explanation: By calling the people 'rebellion' itself, the verse uses the language of political insurrection to conceptualize their refusal to heed God’s words, treating religious disobedience as treason against a sovereign.

deliberation: Two figurative elements stand out: (1) the repeated designation בֵּית הַמֶּרִי ('the rebellious house'), again metonymic for the community, and (2) the command 'open your mouth and eat what I am giving you,' which initiates the enacted metaphor of consuming a scroll. Even before the scroll is revealed, 'eat what I give you' clearly extends food imagery to receiving God’s message.

deliberation: The phrase 'a hand stretched out to me' (יָד שְׁלוּחָה אֵלָי) is the main candidate. Within the vision, a disembodied hand appears to deliver the scroll. This is an anthropomorphic-metonymic representation: 'hand' stands for the divine (or angelic) agent and for active power. I treat that as one instance of metonymy with anthropomorphic coloring.

deliberation: Assessed whether the description of the scroll 'written on both the front and the back' and the triad 'lamentations, dirges, and woes' involve merism, hyperbole, or metaphor. The double-sided writing underscores fullness but is simply a physical description of the scroll; the listed terms denote types of lament without transferring meaning from another domain. The verse is vivid but not overtly figurative in the technical sense requested.
